title: CeMbio Screen 96WP

source.description: Using an eyebrow hairpick, pick 10 L4-stage N2 worms onto each of 10 OP50-seeded 90mm petri plates 4 days prior to bleaching (e.g. on Monday if bleaching on Friday).
On day of bleaching (e.g. Friday 2pm) follow the protocol for Bleach synchronisation of C. elegans:

source.title: Bleach synchronisation of C. elegans
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"aisuj","text":"This protocol is for obtaining synchronised populations of C. elegans. Eggs are harvested from gravid hermaphrodites and allow to grow to L1 arrest for 12-120 hours (0.5-5days). L1 larvae are then fed and left to develop to the appropriate developmental stage","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":59,"length":10,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

Re-feed arrested L1 larvae approximately 72 hours prior to tracking (e.g. on Monday if tracking on Thursday), following the steps outlined in the above protocol for Bleach synchronisation of C. elegans.
Store the refed L1 plates in 20°C incubator.

source.title: Making LB NGM agar imaging plates (96WP)

source.description:
2 days prior to tracking (e.g. on Tuesday if tracking on Thursday), make 500ml LB NGM agar following the protocol Making LB NGM Plates:
Post-autoclave salts:

source.title: Making LB NGM Plates
source.description: {"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2vh1c","text":"C. elegans is maintained in the laboratory on Nematode Growth Medium (NGM) agar which has been aseptically poured into petri plates. Sometimes they can also be grown on LB-NGM, where the LB in the media will promote better growth of the bacteria the worms feed on. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dvg99","text":"The LB-NGM agar medium can be poured into petri plates easily and aseptically using a peristaltic pump. This pump can be adjusted so that a constant amount of LB-NGM agar is dispensed into each petri plate. A constant amount of agar in the plates reduces the need for refocusing the microscope when you switch from one plate to another.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]}

source.title: Making LB NGM agar imaging plates (96WP)

source.description: Using the Integra ViaFill, dispense 200ul of LB NGM agar into 96-well imaging plates, following the protocol Dispensing agar into multiwell plates:

source.title: Dispensing agar into multiwell plates
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"fmd1o","text":"Protocol for pouring agar into 96 well plates using Integra VIAFILL dispenser. Agar should be prepared in advance, and kept in 60oC waterbath until ready to dispense, and whilst dispensing. The X, Y, Z positions for dispensing can be adjusted according to the multiwell plates being used. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":129,"length":1,"style":"sup"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

source.title: Making LB NGM agar imaging plates (96WP)

source.description: Leave the plates on the lab bench (with lids on) until the agar is dry.

3 days prior to tracking (e.g. on Tuesday if tracking Thursday), inoculate overnight cultures of bacterial strains in 96-well from 96-well CeMbio frozen stock plates, following the protocol for Growing overnight bacterial culture in 96WP:
Place inoculated cultures in 96WP in a shaking incubator at 25°C, 200rpm.

source.title: Growing overnight bacterial culture in 96WP
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"6cl0l","text":"Luria broth (LB) is a nutrient-rich media commonly used to culture bacteria in the lab. LB agar plates are frequently used to isolate individual (clonal) colonies of bacteria carrying a specific plasmid. However, a liquid culture is capable of supporting a higher density of bacteria and is used to grow up sufficient numbers of bacteria necessary to isolate enough plasmid DNA for experimental use. The following protocol is for inoculating an overnight culture of liquid LB with bacteria. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7pbn7","text":"This is a general protocol for making a liquid bacterial culture in 96-well plate format from frozen stock plates.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9oo94","text":"The following parameters need to be mentioned for the specific type of bacterial strains inoculated:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"coanl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4v8sm","text":"     Parameters      Example        1. Name\/s of the bacterial strain      OP50        2. Growth temperature      37C        3. Incubation time      16-18hrs        4. Antibiotic resistance (if any)      None        5. Rpm of the shaking incubator (if needed)      200-220 rpm if required   ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":291,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"5riap","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5k9h8","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4n17u","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"tables","data":{"cellsMeta":{"0_0":"","0_1":"","1_0":"","1_1":"","2_0":"","2_1":"","3_0":"","3_1":"","4_0":"","4_1":"","5_0":"","5_1":""},"colWidths":[200,200],"data":[["  Parameters  ","  Example  "],["  1. Name\/s of the bacterial strain  ","  OP50  "],["  2. Growth temperature  ","  37C  "],["  3. Incubation time  ","  16-18hrs  "],["  4. Antibiotic resistance (if any)  ","  None  "],["  5. Rpm of the shaking incubator (if needed)  ","  200-220 rpm if required  "]],"guid":"4C53DC6A8AE811EAAF890A58A9FEAC2A","legend":"","mergeCells":[],"rowHeights":[23,23,23,23,23,23],"show_headers":true}}]}

The next day (e.g. Wednesday, 1 day prior to tracking), remove overnight cultures from the shaking incubators and replace the LB in each of the wells of the inoculated 96WPs (that are reserved for the control bacterial strain) with 200ul OP50 bacterial culture that was inoculated separately.

source.title: Dispensing Day1 worms onto seeded plates using COPAS (96WP)

source.description: On the day of tracking (e.g. Thursday, if re-feeding was performed on Monday), remove seeded plates from 4°C, and dry for 30 mins under a hood.
After acclimation under the Hydra rigs, record worm behaviour on the bacterial food for 15 minutes (25fps, exposure 25000msec, bluelight stimulation).
Record 15 minute videos at the following timepoints: 1, 3, 5, and 24 hours on food.
After tracking, discard the plates in a biological waste bin.
Separately inoculate 100ml E. coli OP50 bacteria in an Erlenmeyer flask and place in a shaking incubator at 37°C, 200rpm.
Remove imaging plates from 4°C storage and record the average weight of 3 of the plates.
Place seeded plates to dry under a hood for about 30 minutes.
Store the bacterial cultures at 4°C until seeding bacterial lawns later that day.
Once imaging plates are dry, remove bacterial cultures from 4°C and seed 10ul bacterial culture into 96-well imaging plates, following the protocol Seeding bacterial lawns using Integra ViaFlo (96WP)

source.title: Making LB NGM agar imaging plates (96WP)

source.description: Measure the weight of 3 plates (with lids on) and record average plate weight on day of pouring.

source.title: Making LB NGM agar imaging plates (96WP)

source.description: Store the plates upside-down at 4°C (plates can be stored for up to 1 week prior to use).
Place the imaging plates in a drying cabinet for approximately 2-3 hours (until the plates have lost approximately 3-5% of their original weight).

source.title: Dispensing Day1 worms onto seeded plates using COPAS (96WP)

source.description: Dispense Day1 worms onto seeded plates for imaging, following the protocol Using the worm sorter (COPAS):

source.title: COPAS wormsorter
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"66sl","text":"Protocol for dispensing adult worms using the COPAS 500 flowpilot","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}
Leave seeded plates on the lab bench (with lids on) for 4 hours to allow lawns to grow.
Keep the tube with bleached worms on a rotator in an incubator at 20°C until re-feeding (maximum 5 days post-bleaching, as behaviour is not consistent after this time frame).

source.title: Dispensing Day1 worms onto seeded plates using COPAS (96WP)

source.description: Remove worms on 90mm Petri plates from 20°C incubator, and follow the protocol Preparing worms for the COPAS (wormsorter):

source.title: Preparing worms for the COPAS (wormsorter)
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"5gfrg","text":"This protocol is a guide of how to prepare the worms to be used in the COPAS (wormsorter)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}
Store seeded plates at 4°C overnight.

source.title: Dispensing Day1 worms onto seeded plates using COPAS (96WP)

source.description: Leave plates to dry under a hood for 30 minutes.

source.title: Dispensing Day1 worms onto seeded plates using COPAS (96WP)

source.description: Place plates in the imaging cave under the Hydra rigs to acclimate for 30 minutes prior to imaging (+1hr timepoint).

description: Protocol for behavioural screening of Caenorhabditis elegans response to bacteria from its natural microbiome (CeMbio)
